Hi @lkoenig this goes against one of the projects code standards : https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#don-t-abuse-kwargs

the drivers explicitly use named arguments to allow people to see from the docs what the arguments are, which are required, which are optional. etc.

create_node is intended to be used directly for all drivers. 

please can you explain your use case with a bit more context so we might be able to help?

@crunk1 build passed, merged. 
@erjohnso I know its the long weekend so enjoy!

A couple of more things.

Besides that, LGTM, +1

Thanks @tonybaloney for that feedback. I had read that documentation prior submitting the pull request. My issue is I didn't see that working with the implentation of libcloud.compute.base.deploy_node as that methode, line 902 of the file base.py call

``` python
        node = self.create_node(**kwargs)
```

Which, in the case of the azure driver, will throw an exception (as create_node in the azure driver expects some positional argument)

Have you a way you can recommand to fix that ?
I saw 2 ways:
- Make the create_node of the azure driver use only kwargs (like the one in openstack and other) even if that breaks the policy yo mentionned
- Change how the deploy_node takes and passes argument. To me that require a bigger change (maybe compltely worthed, but as I am new to the project, I prefer to ask).

Thanks again for your help,
Lionel
PS: I'll check also the UT failure ;)

@lkoenig everything in base.NodeDriver is meant to be overridden, if you don't override it, normally there is a NotImplementedError to catch you. 
In the case of the Azure driver it looks like it doesn't match up the arguments correctly, so you want to override deploy_node with your own implementation.

Here's an example creating a node with Azure https://github.com/mistio/mist.io/blob/master/src/mist/io/methods.py#L2315 

Is it deploy_node you want to use or create_node?

I would like to leverage the deploy_node method of the drive.
According to the documentation of deploy_node, one should not overwrite that method
As stated line 829 of libcloud/compute/base.py:

```
       Deploy node is typically not overridden in subclasses.  The
        existing implementation should be able to handle most such.
```

Thus, to make then the create_node of the azure driver be able to work with the deploy_node, I did the change proposed.

Another alternatives would have been to change the deploy_node to be something like:

``` python
def deploy_node(self, *args, **kwargs):
    # (...)
    self.create_node(*args, **kwargs)
    # (...)
```

Let me know if you prefer another way to solve that issue.
Thanks @tonybaloney!

It appears that unittest in python 2.6 does not have setUpClass...

Interesting... libcloud/testing/__init__.py:27 shows that they try to mitigate that problem with python 2.6's unittest module by importing unittest2 (which is 2.7's module). But that seems to not be working.

@Kami comment?
Could be setup.py:21. It looks like the TestRunner is getting imported from Python 2.6's unittest module, which would explain why setUpClass isn't being called.

@tonybaloney is right - we should always explicitly declare arguments when possible. Sadly some of the old / legacy code doesn't do that, but we should avoid adding more debt in the future when possible.

There are two things we could do:
1. Leave `create_node` signature as it is and also add `**kwargs` to the end
2. Update / fix `deploy_node` so it doesn't pass `deploy_node` specific arguments to `create_node`. We could probably do something simple like this:

``` python
create_node_kwargs = copy.deepcopy(kwargs)
# remove all the deploy_node specific arguments from create_node_kwargs
node = create_node(**create_node_kwargs)
```

I think second option is the way to go. First one makes it work, but it doesn't really solve the "kwargs abuse" problem - method will just silently take in all the additional arguments and ignore them (that makes for a very bad, confusing and unfriendly API).

Thanks for the inputs. I totally agree that explicit argument is way better that kwargs. I am totally for not building up technical debt.
I'll try to implement the second solution as it seems elegant and doing the work. I'll get back as soon as I have something working.

Alright, added the tests and fixed some things.

I will go ahead and merge it and implement pagination in a future PR (driver is already functional without pagination as long as you have < page size number of zones and records).

Yeah, timeout is already automatically passed along in the slurped `**kwargs`:

https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/common/base.py#L1099

But it's the per request timeout, not the whole polling loop timeout.  We should probably disambiguate them and add a new kwarg for `PollingConnection` that gets passed along, IMO.
thanks @smaffulli should we leave documentation somewhere pointing users to the openstack driver?
That's a great idea, thanks for suggesting it. Any suggestion of where would be a good place to mention that?

famous last words. I've CR'ed this but I'm sure it could do with a second pair of eyes. @Kami @runseb or @erjohnso would be appreciated.

I was thinking more about this.  I think we should rename `timeout` on `PollingConnection` to be `async_timeout` or something, and then let it be passed along in the `__init__` as an argument.  This would require modifying a few classes that inherit from `PollingConnection` but having the same property (`timeout`) mean two things is confusing.

LGTM, +1
On a related note - it might also be a good idea (improvement) to throw in `set_http_proxy` method if the provided url is None / not valid.

@poliveira89

> @tonybaloney do you use it in a dev or prod environment?
> If this PR is accepted, could lead to create providers for Swarm, Kubernetes and other Container implementations as well?

Similar to libvirt, a lot of docker functionality doesn't really nicely map to the libcloud.compute.\* API which was primarily designed to handle cloud and virtual servers.

If we decide to also add support for other container run-times (docker, rkt, FreeBsD jails, Solaris zones, etc.) it would be worth evaluating if we should create a new `libcloud.container` API which is primarily targeted and designed for containers.

In any case, if we go with a new API it's also worth noting that that's a much bigger task and commitment.

Also as far as Swarm and Kubernetes goes - those are more of container orchestrator systems so I don't think they fit well in either compute or potential new container API.

@poliveira89 @Kami @runseb 

I can see 3 options for us here (if we target docker and then rkt)
1) proceed with docker as a compute driver, the implementation is a bit wonky but it works
2) create a new driver type, ContainerNodeDriver, which INHERITS from NodeDriver, list_nodes would be overloaded to return ContainerNode's instead of Nodes. a ContainerNode (which inherits from Node) would share the same properties, but also have an additional property stating which Node it belongs to. There would be some other methods like pull_image, etc. That way users can use list_nodes etc. but also take advantage of the other functions.
3) create a new driver type, ContainerDriver and start from scratch, just design and implement which methods based on usage

For the record. I favor option 2.
Thank you. Do I need to do something with the Jira ticket? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-782

@Kami  let me start this comment, by saying that I fully understand that this "upgrade" or embracing Containers will be a much bigger task and require a lot effort from everyone involved (because as you stated some changes - design and implementation must be discussed). I just asked to inquire which was the roadmap regarding this topic - for Container-as-a-Service providers.

But, if you allow me to say this, before anyone start this undertaking, why don't start small? First discuss the acceptance of this PR... as @tonybaloney and @mgogoulos states, this works perfectly for their use-case scenario (which, I assume, is deploy instances/nodes regardless of the provider).
After, that the community and the Libcloud team could start the discussion of a more serious a well-developed solution regarding that alongside this there are some consortiums discussing standards for containers.

After reading, @tonybaloney last post, I still does not have a well defined opinion, because I'm questioning (because I'm not seeing at first) what is the major differences that requires a differente object Driver for Containers?

To finalize, IMHO, I think that considering Docker as a provider of Libcloud is not that farfetch, because, I may be wrong, but you support Digital Ocean and other providers which works with Docker Daemon/Client to deploy containers. 
Source: https://docs.docker.com/machine/drivers/
LGTM +1
